â€œThe surgery was really good. It was difficult surgery as the meniscus was really bad. The first six weeks were hard, but since I left the hospital, I have been working two times a day. The first two months are important with that type of injury, with the extension of the leg and flexing the most important thing. Then you have to build more muscle in that leg as the muscle has completely gone. In 10 to 12 days, I can start doing the bike and walking and leave the crutches! I am happy at that and looking forward to every day.â€
Gerard Deulofeu on the road to recovery ğŸ™Œ

ğŸ’› Find out about the amazing work of Healing Hands - Helping the NHS to heal!
Healing Hands - Helping the NHS to heal
April 2 at 1:36 PM Â·
The amazing NHS angels are struggling!!
They spend 12 hour shifts in PPE, gloves and masks and are ending up with dry hands and faces......We want to help them any way possible!!
We are a small group of local ladies who have noticed a need for hand and face creams for the NHS staff.
We are asking our community to help us help our NHS!
Our aim is to provide drop boxes where the general public can drop off new, unused face or hand creams for the NHS staff which we can then take to the local hospitals.
It is such a simple idea but we really believe its a small way of saying thanks to all those amazing NHS angels.

One year on...
Relive a special day at Wembley as Gerard Deulofeu came off the bench to score twice as the Hornets beat Wolves 3-2 in extra time in the FA Cup semi-final.
Matt Doherty and Raul Jimenez had put Wolves 2-0 up and destined for the FA Cup Final, before Deulofeu's magical finish halved the deficit.
Troy Deeney then won and converted a 90th minute penalty, before Deulofeu completed an amazing comeback in extra-time to send the Hornets to their first FA Cup Final since 1984!
Watch the semi-final highlights in a cinematic recap!

ğŸ’¬ Craig Cathcart: â€œAway from football I like to focus on my family as I find it takes your mind away from the game. I used to do things like playing on the PlayStation quite a lot but itâ€™s just not possible when youâ€™ve got three kids running around different places. My kids are two, six and seven and my oldest daughter was only two when we moved down to Watford so this feels like home more than anywhere else to us as a family. They love their school and they have a lot of friends here, so weâ€™re really settled. When I find time I do like watching other sports, especially boxing. I also watch snooker every now and then when itâ€™s on. I recently bought a VR headset to try and the kids really like some of the games on there, so I do get to do a little bit of game-playing too!

I was very young when me and my family left the Democratic Republic of Congo but as I was growing up my parents told me almost everything about the difficulties of living there. It was impossible for us, so we moved to Belgium. It was not an easy decision for them to take because they left a lot of family behind, but they thought first of all about us and I thank them every day for that. My grandmother and aunts and most of my family are still there. I still follow the political situation there because even if Iâ€™m not living there, it is still my home country. Itâ€™s in my plan to go back there some day but I havenâ€™t found the right moment to do so yet.
From DR Congo to Watford via Belgium, Christian Kabasele has a remarkable story ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡ªğŸ’›

ğŸ’¬ â€œThe club have done a really good job, to be honest. About 10-12 days ago when it was looking as though this situation could be likely, they delivered equipment to our houses so we could set up home gyms and then they set up programmes for us. Itâ€™s been pretty self-explanatory. I do a lot of work on the bike, probably an hour every morning, and then some days Iâ€™ll do some strength work or go out for a run. The club have done a really good job to make sure itâ€™s as easy as possible for the players to do the work to keep fit.â€

â„¹ï¸ Watford FC fully supports the Premier Leagueâ€™s decision to suspend fixtures due to the coronavirus outbreak.
â€œFirst and foremost, our concern is for the wellbeing of everybody connected with our club; players, staff and supporters,â€ said Hornetsâ€™ Chairman & CEO Scott Duxbury.
â€œOur actions in recent weeks to take extra precautionary steps reflect the fact that this has always been our priority; something our Head Coach Nigel Pearson reiterated fully at this morningâ€™s press conference.â€
He added: â€œWe will continue our usual lines of communication with our supporters, providing the most up-to-date information possible.â€

â€œWe've had players who have had symptoms of not being well. We've got one player awaiting tests results on his symptoms. We are trying to be proactive and hopefully the Premier League will make a strong decision based on what is good for everybody. â€œWe have to make sure the well-being of everybody concerned is taken care of first and foremost.â€
Nigel Pearson gives his thoughts on the current Coronavirus situation as he takes part in his usual pre-match press conference.

I can still remember the people outside in the city celebrating the victory and all the celebrations on the Champs-Ã‰lysÃ©es. All the French people were so happy and the teamâ€™s performance inspired a lot of people because we had a bright future ahead. â„¹ï¸ Today's postponed Emirates FA Cup third round replay with Tranmere Rovers will now take place on Thursday, January 23 at 7.45pm.
A statement from The FA read: â€œAfter consultation with all the relevant parties, in order to keep the Competition on track and reduce the risk of causing fixture disruption elsewhere, the match has been rescheduled for Thursday January 23, 7.45pm kick-off.
â€œThe winner of this tie will host Wolverhampton Wanderers or Manchester United in the Fourth Round Proper on Sunday 26 January, 3.00pm kick-off, live on BT Sport.â€

We're pleased to announce the permament signing of Argentinian winger Ignacio Pussetto from Udinese Calcio 1896.
The versatile 24-year-old, who can also operate as a striker or an attacking midfielder, has agreed terms on a four-and-a-half-year contract.
Welcome Ignacio ğŸ™Œ

Tonight's Emirates FA Cup third round replay against Tranmere Rovers has been postponed, following heavy rainfall from Storm Brendan at Prenton Park since Sunday.
Both clubs were in regular contact with each other, the referee and the Football Association over the past two days, discussing the options available.
However, following a pitch inspection this afternoon, the referee decided the match unfortunately could not go ahead.
The date for the rescheduled match will follow as soon as possible.

â€œI grew up in Freetown, Sierra Leone, but I donâ€™t really have many memories from back then. I went back there this summer and it was just an eye opener; thereâ€™s real poverty over there. I hear some of the stories and my Dad tells me bits and pieces here and there. I moved to England when I was seven and football made the move easier. I spoke Krio, which is kind of broken English, so I could speak fluent English pretty quickly. I would always go and find a football at break times at school and play with my mates. When people started to comment on my ability it made me more confident and I grew as a person.â€

â€œI buy boots one size bigger as they are the only boots I could find for 10 pounds. It sounds weird, but it's real. My feet hurt a lot, I had to put them in ice when I got in from work as it was so, so painful.â€œ
I was so, so bad. I didn't sleep well. I was so stressed. I was anxious a lot. I broke my [front] teeth through grinding in the night. I missed my dog. I couldn't see my parents and my partner was working the night shifts at Pret a Manger as she was studying during the day as we needed more money. It was so hard. One day, I said, 'I need to change, even if we have less money, even if we just pay the bills and nothing else. I don't care. I can't sleep 20 hours a week. I'm sorry.'â€

text: Where in the world will you be watching the @EmiratesFACup Final from? ğŸŒ
Thank you India for your good wishes for our FA Cup Final #ImagineIf

Five eras!
Five squads!
But only one 5-a-side team!
Pick one player from each year and build your dream Watford team... ğŸ¤”

We've already had one special day at Wembley this season...
Take a look at the top ğŸ”Ÿ moments from that famous occasion!

#ImagineIf a young man caught up in the gang culture on the streets of his hometown could reach the FA Cup final.
Andre Gray has walked a path few have taken before him. Growing up looking over his shoulder, watching out for cars he didnâ€™t recognise, to the life-changing moment he was stabbed in the face, the Watford striker has persevered through adversity.
Now he is days away from walking out in front of thousands of Hornets fans at the national stadium to try and help Watford land a first trophy in their history.
This is his story, in his own words.
#ImagineIf we showed Jose Holebas our Twitter mentions and got him to answer back...Well imagine no more!

Anyone who knows Watford, knows. Weâ€™ve had amazing highs, but all too often, theyâ€™re followed by equally painful lows.
Watch players, staff and fans talk through the great moments of 1984, 1999, 2006 and 2013 but then reflect on the difficult periods that followed each.
#ImagineIf, in 2019, things are different.

FT | Everton 3-2 #watfordfc
The Hornets let a two-goal lead slip as they fall to a third successive defeat in the Premier League.
Watford were seemingly in control after Richarlison and Kabasele goals after the break, but the Toffees fought back through Niasse, Calvert-Lewin and an injury-time Baines penalty to seal all three points at Goodison Park.
There was nearly a late lifeline for the Hornets, but Cleverley dragged a penalty wide deep into stoppage time.

ğŸ’¬ | "We didn't deserve this result. I'm really proud how we played."
Marco Silva rues missed chances, but proud of his #watfordfc team's display at Stamford Bridge yesterday.
â¡ http://bit.ly/2yZo7ZO

FT | Chelsea 4-2 #watfordfc
A final scoreline which was harsh on the Hornets.
After Doucoure cancelled out Pedro's opener on the stroke of half-time, Pereyra handed Watford a 2-1 lead shortly after the break.
The Hornets were left to rue missed chances - two fantastic opportunities in particular for Richarlison - as Batshuayi pulled Chelsea level and then Azpilicueta headed the hosts in front with three minutes to go.
Deep into injury-time, Batshuayi added a fourth, but this was no walkover for the Blues, who ultimately inflicted a first away defeat of the season on Watford.

FULL-TIME: Everton 1-0 #watfordfc

Deeney and Okaka both went close after the break - the former turned Janmaat's cross wide at the near post, and the latter saw a clever turn and volley kept out by Everton keeper Robles.

FULL-TIME: Crystal Palace 1-0 #watfordfc
The Eagles took all three points at Selhurst Park, despite not registering a shot on target throughout. It was a Troy Deeney own goal which ultimately settled matters - the Hornets' captain headed into his own net from Yohan Cabaye's free-kick midway through the second-half.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

HALF-TIME: Crystal Palace 0-0 #watfordfc
An even first-half ends goalless at Selhurst Park. There's been little to trouble either keeper thus far, M'Baye Niang drawing a routine save from Wayne Hennessey 25 yards from goal, and Yohan Cabaye seeing a shot deflected wide at the other end after Younes Kaboul had headed away a Wilfried Zaha cross.

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 3-4 Southampton
Dusan Tadic and Nathan Redmond overturned Troy Deeney's fourth-minute volley to hand the Saints a 2-1 lead at the break.
Stefano Okaka converted Isaac Success' cross to equalise with 10 minutes to, but quickfire goals from Manolo Gabbiadini and Redmond effectively sealed all three points for the visitors.
Abdoulaye Doucoure tapped home his first Watford goal right at the death, but it was too little, too late for the Hornets.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 1-2 Southampton
For the second weekend running, the Hornets were off to a flying start. Troy Deeney volleyed in Stefano Okaka's layoff to open the scoring in the fourth minute.
But the Saints bounced back through Dusan Tadic, who equalised on 28 minutes, then Nathan Redmond scored via the post in first-half stoppage time.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 1-1 West Ham
Honours even in the end at Vicarage Road. Troy Deeney handed the Hornets the lead with a third-minute penalty, after Mauro Zarate - who was later strechered off with a knee injury - had been fouled by Cheikhou Kouyate.
Sub Andre Ayew salvaged a point for the Hammers with 17 minutes to go, tapping into the empty net after Michail Antonio's shot hit both posts.
West Ham's Antonio was dismissed for a second booking on 86 minutes, but despite some late pressure the Golden Boys were unable to find the winning goal.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 1-0 West Ham
Troy Deeney converted a third-minute penalty after Mauro Zarate had been tripped by Cheikhou Kouyate in the area, in what was an excellent start from the Hornets.
There was concern late on for Zarate though, who was stretchered off with what looked like a knee injury during stoppage time.
Abdoulaye Doucoure has been introduced as the ex-Hammer's replacement.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 2-1 Burnley
Three more points for the Hornets! First-half headers from Troy Deeney and M'Baye Niang win it for Walter Mazzarri's side, who played against 10 men since the sixth minute after Jeff Hendrick's sending off for a two-footed tackle. Ashley Barnes pulled one back from the penalty spot with 12 minutes to go, but the Hornets held on and are now four unbeaten in the Premier League.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

ğŸ“·ğŸ¯
A wonderful angle of M'Baye Niang's header that put #watfordfc 2-0 just prior to the break at Vicarage Road!

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 2-0 Burnley
Great first 45 minutes from the Hornets! Jeff Hendrick was shown a straight red card for a two-footed tackle on Jose Holebas, leaving the Clarets down to 10 men after just six minutes. Troy Deeney capitalised with a 10th-minute header from M'Baye Niang's cross, then in stoppage time at the end of the half, the AC Milan loanee nodded home his first in Watford colours after Holebas' near-post delivery.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 2-0 Burton Albion
The Hornets secure passage to the Fourth Round of the FA Cup courtesy of goals from Christian Kabasele and Jerome Sinclair either side of half-time.
Head to watfordfc.com for post-match reaction as we get it. Come on you 'Orns!

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 1-0 Burton Albion
Full debutant Brandon Mason bagged an assist for Christian Kabaele's goal which separates the two sides at Vicarage Road.
It's been a quiet opening 45 minutes, Etienne Capoue's rasping drive and Ighalo's effort over the bar the only other chances of note.

TEAM NEWS: #watfordfc v Burton Albion
Live commentary at watfordfc.com now!
Brandon Mason makes his first start for the senior side after impressing as a substitute against Tottenham on New Years' Day.
Costel Pantilimon replaces Heurelho Gomes in goal as the Brazilian shot-stopper is sidelined through illness.
Jerome Sinclair and Odion Ighalo both start after coming off the bench against Stoke in the midweek Premier League fixture.
Craig Cathcart replaces Sebastian PrÃ¶dl in the starting eleven as he looks to improve his match fitness after a long injury layoff.

FULL-TIME: Manchester City 2-0 #watfordfc
It's all over at The Etihad where a goal in each half from Pablo Zabaleta and David Silva earned the home side all three points.
The Hornets did have chances to find the back of the net, with Odion Ighalo coming the closest but the forward could only fire over when well placed in-front of Claudio Bravo's goal.

HALF-TIME: Manchester City 1-0 #WatfordFC
The hosts lead by one at the break courtesy of Pablo Zabaleta's strike.
Apart from a couple of Watford crosses from the right-hand side, Pep Guardiola's men have been well on top. But, it's still only 1-0, and while it stays that way the Hornets have a chance.

"There was no doubt who deserved the victory."
Walter Mazzarri says #watfordfc were good value for their 1-0 win over Hull City yesterday. He was also particularly pleased to see a return to action for Daryl Janmaat.
More here: http://bit.ly/MazzarriHullReaction

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 1-0 Hull City
A fully deserved three points for the Hornets, who win thanks to a Michael Dawson own-goal with eight minutes to go. That's four games unbeaten for Watford, who have also kept three consecutive clean sheets.

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 0-0 Hull City
Goalless at the break, but the Hornets have been the better side. Younes Kaboul and Roberto Pereyra both hit the woodwork during the opening stages, while Troy Deeney and Sebastian PrÃ¶dl each saw headers go wide later in the half.

TEAM NEWS: #watfordfc v Hull Tigers
One change for the Hornets today as Nordin Amrabat replaces Camilo Zuniga at right wing-back. Daryl Janmaat is back on the bench after a shoulder injury.
HORNETS: Gomes (GK); Kaboul, PrÃ¶dl, Britos; Amrabat, Pereyra, Behrami, Capoue, Holebas; Deeney (c), Ighalo.
Subs: Pantilimon (GK), Kabasele, Janmaat, Zuniga, Watson, Guedioura, Sinclair.
TIGERS: Marshall (GK), Maguire, Davies, Hernandez, Clucas, Livermore, Keane, Dawson (c), Henriksen, Mason, Elmohamady.

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 2-2 Bournemouth
Troy Deeney hauled the Hornets level five minutes after the break with a close-range finish to Nordin Amrabat's cross, after Callum Wilson's first-half header.
Josh King restored Bournemouth's lead moments after his introduction from the bench, but it was another sub - in the shape of Isaac Success - who headed Watford's 65th-minute equaliser, his first goal for the Golden Boys.

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 0-1 Bournemouth
The Cherries lead through Callum Wilson's 31st-minute header after a Junior Stanislas cross from the right-flank.
Nordin Amrabat went closest for the Hornets, with two efforts in quick succession which were saved by keeper Artur Boruc late in the half.

TEAM NEWS: #watfordfc v AFC Bournemouth
Two changes for the Hornets, with Camilo Zuniga and Younes Kaboul replacing Craig Cathcart (hip) and Miguel Britos (thigh).
Also missing this afternoon are Daryl Janmaat (shoulder), Adrian Mariappa (sickness), Stefano Okaka (hamstring) and Jerome Sinclair (hamstring).

Subs: Pantilimon (GK), Kabasele, Kenedy, Watson, Doucoure, Guedioura, Success.

FULL-TIME: Burnley 2-0 #watfordfc
It was a disappointing night in Lancashire as goals from corners in either half condemned Watford to a 2-0 defeat at the hands of newly-promoted Burnley.
Backed by an outstanding 1,415 travelling supporters, the Hornets failed to produce in front of the Monday Night Football TV cameras and fell to their first defeat on the road this season.
Jeff Hendrick headed the Clarets in-front late in the first-half, and Michael Keane scored via the same method five minutes after the break as the Golden Boys struggled to deal defensively with the visitorsâ€™ set-pieces.

HALF-TIME: Burnley 1-0 #watfordfc
Jeff Hendrick's 38th-minute header has given the Clarets a deserved lead at the break. The midfielder rose highest from a Steven Defour corner to nod inside the far post during a disappointing opening 45 minutes for the Hornets.

TEAM NEWS: #watfordfc v Burnley
One change for the Hornets following last weekend's win over Manchester United, with Nordin Amrabat replacing Daryl Janmaat (shoulder). Younes Kaboul is back on the bench after recovering from a hamstring problem.

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 3-1 Manchester United
The Hornets' first win over United in 30 years!
Marcus Rashford cancelled out Etienne Capoue's first-half opener just after the hour, but Walter Mazzarri's men battled on and super-sub Camilo Zuniga drilled into the bottom corner moments after his introduction to hand the Golden Boys a deserved 83rd-minute lead.
And there was more, Troy Deeney smashed home a stoppage time penalty after Marouane Fellaini's trip on Zuniga, sending the superb Watford fans into delirium.
An historic afternoon at The Vic!
Re-live all the action as it happened here: http://bit.ly/WFCMatchdayLive

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 1-0 Manchester United
Etienne Capoue's fourth goal in five games has the Hornets ahead against Jose Mourinho's men at the break. The midfielder smashed home from inside the box after receiving a cut-back from Daryl Janmaat. It's no less than Watford deserve, with Odion Ighalo and Troy Deeney also going close.

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 1-3 Arsenal
A much-improved second-half showing from the Hornets, with half-time substitute Pereyra scoring a debut goal 57 minutes in, hooking home after Capoue's initial effort had been blocked. But the damage was done before the break, Cazorla's penalty and goals from Alexis and Ozil firing the Gunners into a three-goal lead.

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 0-3 Arsenal
The Gunners took a controversial ninth-minute lead when Cazorla slotted home a penalty after Amrabat was ruled to have fouled Alexis in the area. That advantage was doubled by Alexis, whose shot just crossed the line following a 40th-minute Walcott cross, and in stoppage time at the end of the first-half Ozil ghosted into the box to head home a third.

TEAM NEWS: #watfordfc v Arsenal

Two changes from Watford's last Premier League game against Chelsea. Kaboul & Kabasele come in for Cathcart (groin) & Britos (partner due to give birth). There's a Watford debut for Kaboul today. Janmaat, Success & Pereyra on the bench for the first time.

FULL-TIME (AET): #watfordfc 1-2 Gillingham
The Hornets exit the EFL Cup in the second round after falling to League One side Gillingham at The Vic.
Odion Ighalo handed the Hornets a 58th-minute lead, two minutes after his introduction as a substitute, and then Bradley Dack skied a penalty as the Gills threatened to equalise.
They were level with eight minutes to go though, Mark Byrne finding the bottom corner with a curling effort which sent the game into extra-time.
Dack atoned for his earlier spot-kick miss with 102 minutes played, bundling marginally over the line from close-range to send the visitors through to the third round.

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 0-0 Gillingham
Honours even at the break during tonight's EFL Cup Round Two game. Watford have had the better of the chances, but are yet to find a breakthrough. Gills keeper Stuart Nelson has produced a few important saves, keeping out Troy Deeney, Ikechi Anya and Matej Vydra chances.

TEAM NEWS: #watfordfc v Gillingham (EFL Cup Round Two)

Subs: Gomes (GK), Kaboul, Holebas, Zuniga, Capoue, Sinclair, Ighalo.

GALLERY: Here are some action shots from #watfordfc's 2-1 defeat to Chelsea at The Vic this afternoon.

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 1-2 Chelsea
The visitors take all three points after coming back from 1-0 down late on. Etienne Capoue blasted the Hornets into the lead with a superb left-footed volley in the 55th minute, but Chelsea sub Michy Batshuayi equalised from close-range with 10 minutes to go after Heurelho Gomes couldn't hold on to Eden Hazard's low shot. Diego Costa scored the winner in the 87th minute, slotting home after a long ball over the Hornets' defence.

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 0-0 Chelsea
Good first 45 minutes for the Hornets, who had the chance of the half when Odion Ighalo turned just over from close-range after Nordin Amrabat beat Cesar Azpilicueta down the right and delivered an inch-perfect cross.
